column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=CHAP. 12.
#Text=IF the putrefaction proceedeth most of the earth or
#Text=vppermost partes of the earth, as from stinking channells, standing
#Text=lakes, priuyes, or other polluted places, as dunghills, vncleane kept houses,
#Text=and such like, then there will be felt many sudden great stinches, and
#Text=vnsauerie smells, such as cannot be distinguished, or discerned,
#Text=what it is, or whereof it commeth, because it is confounded, beeing made of
#Text=diuers stinches: in that yeare there wil be many frogges, toades, venemous
#Text=wormes, fleas, and flyes.
#Text=CHAP. 13.
#Text=IF the putrefaction proceedeth from within the earth, then
#Text=venemous beasts and wormes will be seene more commonly aboue the earth,
#Text=and will breede vpon the earth, and many of them will die.
#Text=CHAP. 14.
#Text=THe putrefaction or virulent matter of infection now, is from
#Text=celestiall orbes principally, also from corrupt places, partly from
#Text=corrupt humours in man, begotten by the two former, and ill order in feeding
#Text=and sleeping, in idlenes and late walking abroad, and sitting vp.
#Text=CHAP. 15.
#Text=THe infection taken at the nostrills is more daungerous then
#Text=otherwise, because there are two organes or passages that lead to the
#Text=heart, from thence more, then from the mouth.
#Text=CHAP. 16.
#Text=THe putrified aire cannot passe so speedily to mans
#Text=heart, as to diuers other creatures by the instrument of smelling, which
#Text=is couered with a pellicle or filme, which is to be lifted vp before he can
#Text=smell by the ayre or fume: and that pellicle is grosser in man then in
#Text=other creatures: and therefore requireth the hotter or stronger fume to
#Text=mooue it.
#Text=Secondly, the instrument of smelling is placed deeper in the
#Text=head, then in any other creatures.
#Text=Thirdly, the instrument of smelling is
#Text=nigh the braine in man, which with the moysture doth hinder the naturall
#Text=complexion of the instrument of smelling, which is hot and drie,
#Text=attractiue or drawing vnto it.
#Text=CHAP. 17.
#Text=IF the putrefaction in the ayre be more hot then moist, then
#Text=it is more apt to destroy, and to be taken by the nostrills: first,
#Text=because the heat is subtile, and passeth vp speedily to the
#Text=pellicle, and mooueth with the fume or moisture.
#Text=Secondly, for that the heat
#Text=doth resist the coldnes and moisture of the braine, the which are
#Text=hinderers of smelling.
#Text=CHAP. 18.
#Text=The complexion aptest to be infected, is the sanguine,
#Text=first, because the qualities in that complexion are
#Text=like vnto the qualities in the ayre, hot and moist, and therefore doth
#Text=entertaine the ayre the apter.
#Text=Secondly, because these two qualities in
#Text=this complexion maketh it more conuertible, like the ayre, which will sooner
#Text=be made hotter or moister then any of the other elements.
#Text=Thirdly, because
#Text=in this complexion, the passages leading to the humours about the heart,
#Text=and to the vitall spirits in the heart, are more large and spatious then in
#Text=any other.
#Text=The reason is, for that blood naturall is not without his
#Text=vapours, which cause motion, and where most motion of blood is, there is
#Text=cause of extention, and the same is in this complexion.
#Text=CHAP. 19.
#Text=The aptest time for this complexion to entertaine the
#Text=virulent matter into the humours, is in the former spring especially: for
#Text=then blood increaseth, and passeth vp and downe, beeing not thoroughly
#Text=refined, and made the readier by his motion and impuritie to receiue it.
#Text=The aptest time for this complexion to entertaine the
#Text=virulent matter into the spirits vitall is sommer, by reason that the
#Text=blood beeing made hot, and the spirits likewise hot, and ayre continually
#Text=heating.
